entry.title: Portraits of San Diego: a culture of happiness
entry.summary:
National Geographic Photographer Kiliii Y√ºyan is no stranger to travel, often spending months around the globe to understand the world through storytelling and photography. His adventures have taken him high above the Arctic Circle to the depths of tropical waters, capturing imagery of lionfish and other animals.¬†
On a recent trip to San Diego, California, he took his storytelling prowess across the city to learn more about the culture, green and blue spaces, and community. What he found was that the city‚Äôs infectious optimism offered a different kind of thrill. Portraits of San DiegoLearn how this southern California city radiates an infectious brand of joy through the eyes of locals. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs really hard not to feel the joy,‚Äù Y√ºyan says of his time in America‚Äôs finest city. ‚Äú‚Ä¶

entry.title: Can you stand on one leg for 10 seconds? The answer matters for aging.
entry.summary:
If you can‚Äôt comfortably stand on one leg for 10 seconds, your body may be trying to tell you something. ‚ÄúBeing able to stand on one leg is one of the most predictive measurements for aging,‚Äù says Clayton Skaggs, founder of the Central Institute for Human Performance (CIHP), the Karel Lewit Clinic, and Curious Gap Labs.
A 2024 Mayo Clinic study found that the ability to maintain balance standing on one leg indicates how well a person is aging more than strength or gait. Not only does it let us in on someone‚Äôs neuromuscular health, but it can also be a signal of other ailments.¬†
‚ÄúWe utilize [balance] diagnostically to rule in or rule out other diseases,‚Äù says Paraminder Padgett, a neurological clinical specialist and physical therapy clinical supervisor at Dartmouth Hitchcock Medi‚Ä¶

entry.title: The strange role worms play in the birth of baby squid
entry.summary:
An opalescent squid‚Äôs experience of motherhood is almost cruelly brief. Towards the end of her life, she engages in a dramatic reproductive¬†spectacle¬†where, under the glowing moon, a mating frenzy draws large numbers of¬†Doryteuthis opalescens¬†into the shallows to spawn. It‚Äôs a relentless, disorienting ritual characterized by clouds of banana-sized cephalopods flashing red arms‚Äîa mating signal‚Äîand blending together in a haze.
‚ÄúThe seabed and canyon slope, normally a stable point of reference, shifted underneath us as the squid melded in a living current,‚Äù says underwater photojournalist Jules Jacobs, who was there to document the story of the mating phenomenon off La Jolla Shores, California, in an event¬†that can be witnessed at night, typically once a year, if at all. The mating event‚Ä¶

entry.title: Could this be the end of menopause as we know it?
entry.summary:
"We don't have to accept menopause as destiny,‚Äù says Kutluk Oktay, an ovarian biologist and director of the Yale School of Medicine and Director of Laboratory of Molecular Reproduction and Fertility Preservation. Oktay, a leading researcher in fertility preservation, is one of the many scientists in the race to end menopause as we currently understand it.¬†
For most women, menopause means a gradual decline of progesterone and estrogen beginning in their mid-40s. The menopausal transition, or perimenopause, can last between two and eight years, and even up to a decade, before menopause, the point at which a woman‚Äôs menstrual period has stopped for a year. During perimenopause, women can experience a range of associated symptoms, including hot flashes to night sweats, pain during sex, jo‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why running vacations are the next big travel trend
entry.summary:
It‚Äôs almost sunset, and the waterfront M≈±egyetem Wharf is just beginning to stir. The autumn heat, heavy as a weighted blanket, lingers over Budapest, yet a peculiar anticipation hangs in the air as hundreds of people gather for the Generali Night Run Budapest¬†in late August.
The 13-mile route winds through the Hungarian capital‚Äôs heart, taking runners up a 100-meter hill, past the towering Buda Castle, beneath the grand arches of the Chain Bridge, and along the lower embankment, where the illuminated Parliament, Margaret Bridge, and echoing Tunnel unfold like a moving postcard. As the sun bleeds into the Danube, the rhythmic pulse of live bands and the roar of spectators transform the city into a festival of motion and adrenaline, with the night sky as a dramatic backdrop.
Dista‚Ä¶

entry.title: Britain‚Äôs most remote mainland pub is well worth the two-day hike
entry.summary:
Hiker Duncan Lomax travels along the Cape Wrath Trail, usually a 14-day trek from Fort William to Cape Wrath on the northern tip of Scotland. Tucked between sea and mountain, The Old Forge was once a cherished endpoint for hikers‚Äînow, revived by the hands of locals, adventurers are coming back to this iconic watering hole.
We were dropped off at the end of the¬†UK's longest dead-end road. It felt like we had lost contact with the rest of the world. The wilds of¬†Scotland‚Äôs¬†Knoydart¬†region stretched before us‚Äîprimal, remote, and magnetic. Somewhere out there lay¬†The Old Forge, Britain's most remote mainland pub in the tiny village of¬†Inverie. My partner Ines and I love a challenge. But before ordering drinks at the bar, we had two days of hiking ahead‚Äîthrough some of the Highlands' to‚Ä¶

entry.title: This British breakfast classic originated in India
entry.summary:
Kedgeree recipes tend to fall into two camps: a low-waste version suitable for home cooks and a richer, more lavish rendition that would please a royal court. Originating in India during colonial rule and inspired by a traditional dish containing lentils, this combination of rice, smoked fish and egg has become a breakfast favourite in the UK.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Smoked fish flaked into gently spiced rice, topped with egg ‚Äî kedgeree is a beloved breakfast dish that‚Äôs also enjoyed for brunch, lunch and dinner around the UK. Yet its origins can be traced back to India, centuries ago.
It‚Äôs derived from khichdi, a one-pot rice and lentil dish synonymous with both comfort and celebration in South Asia. The earliest written refere‚Ä¶

entry.title: Where does vanilla flavoring come from? Probably not beavers.
entry.summary:
The North American beaver, the largest rodent on the continent, can weigh up to 70 pounds. Castoreum, a substance from sacs near a beaver‚Äôs anus, has been used in human products for more than 2,000 years. Some wonder if it's still an ingredient on today's grocery shelves.
Are there beaver secretions in your vanilla ice cream?
News articles or food influencers on social media might have you believe that castoreum, a yellow, syrupy substance from the castor sacs near a¬†beaver‚Äôs anus, is used as everyday vanilla flavoring, disguised as ‚Äúnatural.‚Äù According to some of these sources, beaver castor is an ingredient in everything from vanilla ice cream to strawberry-flavored oatmeal.
But experts say this couldn‚Äôt be further from the truth. While people have used castoreum for me‚Ä¶

entry.title: How Cowboy Carter reminds us of the Black roots of country music
entry.summary:
Charley Pride, the first Black artist to have a number one country record, achieved immense success in the genre during the 1960s and 1970s, despite facing prejudice and racial discrimination. Artists like Beyonce and Lil Nas X are drawing mainstream attention to a tradition that is alive and well‚Äîthanks to the contributions and innovations of generations of Black musicians.
As Beyonc√© kicks off her Cowboy Carter world tour, her embrace of country music is reigniting conversations about the genre‚Äôs Black roots‚Äîand the pioneers too often left out of its history.
Since Beyonc√© previewed Cowboy Carter during her Super Bowl commercial and released the album in March 2024‚Äîthe second act of her Renaissance trilogy‚Äîthe cultural response has been electric. The Grammy-winning album spo‚Ä¶

entry.title: 6 Las Vegas Day Trips You Have to Experience
entry.summary:
Some of Las Vegas‚Äôs most fascinating attractions lie just outside the city center. Within a few hours‚Äô drive of the home of some of the world‚Äôs best entertainment, travelers will find historic landmarks, unique communities and dramatic natural wonders.
National Geographic photographer Keith Ladzinski has built a career out of finding the best adventures around the world. But on his most recent road trip through some of Nevada‚Äôs lesser-known regions, the abundance of adventures surprised him.¬† When it comes to outdoor recreation, it is an absolute all-star state. Between rock climbing in Arrow Canyon, exploring long-abandoned ghost towns, and stargazing under stunning night skies, Ladzinski discovered the joy that comes from discovering places that might only whisper for your‚Ä¶

entry.title: Your next adventure: Tokyo, Japan
entry.summary:
There‚Äôs a talent to making things beautiful, and in Japan, there‚Äôs a word for it. Monozukuri, which translates to ‚Äúcraftsmanship‚Äù, speaks to the country‚Äôs devotion to high-quality and often visually mesmerizing creations. Precision, patience, and artistry are highly prized, and across Japan‚Äôs eateries, markets, studios, and workshops, travelers are invited to join in.
On a recent journey to Tokyo, National Geographic photographer Jonathan Irish explored hidden gems, bustling neighborhoods, and vibrant cultural districts in this lively, cosmopolitan metropolis, and found that monozukuri abounds.
‚ÄúDespite Tokyo's rapid growth and modern landscape, the city's rich history of craftsmanship remains a timeless part of its identity today,‚Äù says Irish. ‚ÄúI came away with a strong impr‚Ä¶

Into a long protective surgical smock and knee-high rubber waders, and finally, a pair of safety goggles, which‚Äîin the clammy heat of the laboratory complex‚Äîquickly began to fog.

entry.title: Where to travel in June
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
June is the month of plenty. While some parts of the world are braced against hurricanes, monsoons and heat waves, the Northern Hemisphere is in its prime. The southern Med is ripe for striking out on a Croatian sailing tour or crisscrossing the Cyclades, while the Baltic and Nordic countries welcome bright nights and midsummer celebrations.
The dry season starts in safari spots across the globe like Uganda, Tanzania, Borneo and the Peruvian Amazon, making June an ideal time to view the Serengeti‚Äôs Great Migration or orangutans swinging through Sabah rainforests.¬†
The comfortable temperatures also afford opportunities for lovers of the great outdoors, including hiking the mountainous Inca Trail or trekking thr‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why Whistleblowers Need Allies Like Lawyers and Journalists to Expose Corruption
entry.summary: Insiders who successfully sound the alarm often do so with help ‚Äî by partnering with allies who can amplify their message and help shield them from retaliation.

entry.title: These are the rules of king cobra fight club
entry.summary:
The braided motions of two cobra males twisting around each other is so hypnotic that if you didn‚Äôt know better, you might think it was an intimate mating ritual‚Äîand in a way it is.¬†
The 12-foot-long males will wrap around each other for up to half an hour in a highly ritualized struggle to push their opponent‚Äôs face into the dirt with an ignominious thud. Presumably, the snakes spar over access to females. The crazy thing isn‚Äôt so much that they fight, but that these well-known snake eaters and occasional cannibals loaded with toxic venom don‚Äôt choose the most violent path to victory. Instead, the serpents engage in a highly ritualized contest whose rules are implicitly understood by the combatants.
‚ÄúKing cobras are venomous‚Äîthey could easily bite each other and kill each other ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Portable fans are the handy tools that deserve a place in your carry-on
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*¬†
During 2024‚Äôs record high temperatures, handheld portable fans surged in popularity. For travelers, these mini coolers can transcend trends to become a handy addition to a gear kit. But a quick online search reveals that choosing a portable fan isn‚Äôt as simple as it may seem.¬†
For one thing, the best personal fan isn‚Äôt just easy to carry around. It should also be rechargeable, says Sunil Gupta, the co-founder and senior travel adviser at Luxury Ind‚Ä¶

entry.title: This is the most scenic route through Acadia National Park
entry.summary:
Crushed stone crunches under feet, bike tires, and horse hooves on a late spring day in¬†Acadia National Park. Finally free of snow, the popular carriage roads are open, and visitors inhale the spruce-scented air deeply as they meander along the 8.6-mile Jordan Pond Loop. ‚ÄúMy first experience on the carriage roads was when I was growing up in Maine,‚Äù says MacKenzie Bowker, a guide for¬†Summer Feet Cycling & Walking. ‚ÄúI loved cycling with my dad on the roads because it was a quiet place to be and the chances to see wildlife were plentiful.‚Äù
I‚Äôve hiked hundreds of miles on national park trails in the United States, but have biked in far fewer parks because often the only option is to share crowded roads with vehicles. In Acadia, cyclists can enjoy the serenity of nature away from the nois‚Ä¶

entry.title: For a farm-to-table feast, visit Canada‚Äôs smallest province
entry.summary:
On a deserted beach on the far eastern coast of Canada's Prince Edward Island (also known as PEI), chef Nick Chindamo squats among a stand of low-growing weeds, their tips displaying the telltale yellowing of late summer. He rummages for a few seconds before holding out a fat, eight-leaved cluster of sea sandwort, an abundant coastal succulent in northern climates. ‚ÄúTry this,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúIt will surprise you.‚Äù
He‚Äôs right. The leaves, which resemble flattened versions of backyard-garden mainstays like ghost plant, are juicy, with a briny, cucumber-like flavor. Sandwort is among dozens of plants that Chindamo harvests during daily foraging adventures on various patches of scrub, sand, and forest that few would suspect of harboring a trove of edible plants‚Äîand that now make their way onto‚Ä¶

entry.title: Could this be the end of menopause as we know it?
entry.summary:
"We don't have to accept menopause as destiny,‚Äù says Kutluk Oktay, an ovarian biologist and director of the Yale School of Medicine and Director of Laboratory of Molecular Reproduction and Fertility Preservation. Oktay, a leading researcher in fertility preservation, is one of the many scientists in the race to end menopause as we currently understand it.¬†
For most women, menopause means a gradual decline of progesterone and estrogen beginning in their mid-40s. The menopausal transition, or perimenopause, can last between two and eight years, and even up to a decade, before menopause, the point at which a woman‚Äôs menstrual period has stopped for a year. During perimenopause, women can experience a range of associated symptoms, including hot flashes to night sweats, pain during sex, jo‚Ä¶

entry.title: Explore British Columbia with these wild experiences
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
It‚Äôs impossible to resist the call of the wild in British Columbia. This Canadian province on the Pacific has a 17,000-mile coastline lined with mountainous fjords and studded with around 6,000 islands, most of which are uninhabited. Rainforest-fringed shores rise sharply to jagged peaks, home to Canada‚Äôs largest population of grizzlies. Take it all in with floatplane flightseeing, high-altitude hiking, remote kayaking and overnights at wilderness lodges built on Indigenous lands.
Hop aboard a Harbour Air floatplane and let the Pacific Ocean be your runway. Following a remote mail route of yesteryear, a classic De Havilland Canada DHC-2 Beaver will carry you low over BC‚Äôs Gulf Islands ‚Äî scattered between the ‚Ä¶

entry.title: These bats learn to eavesdrop‚Äîin order to survive
entry.summary:
During Panama‚Äôs wet season, forests boom with a chorus of t√∫ngara frog mating calls as males compete for females‚Äô attention.But these calls put the frogs in a precarious position between sex and death. For a fringe-lipped bat, it‚Äôs as though its meal is ringing a dinner bell.¬†
Bats navigate the world with echolocation, listening to the sound waves of their own calls bouncing off nearby objects. Their hearing is so precise they can even home in on prey using ripples that frog calls make on water. undefinedA fringe-lipped bat, Trachops cirrhosus, responds to the calls of the t√∫ngara frog, one of its preferred prey species. The bat hears the call of a single male t√∫ngara frog, producing a complex call (a ‚Äòwhine‚Äô plus multiple ‚Äòchucks‚Äô). The bat then hears the cacophony of a large t√∫‚Ä¶

entry.title: Happiness isn't enough‚Äîhere's why you should strive to 'flourish'
entry.summary:
What really makes for a fulfilling life? This question has been on Tyler J. VanderWeele‚Äôs mind for decades.
In his first faculty job as a biostatistician at the University of Chicago, he was dissatisfied with how scientists defined and measured human well-being. ¬†There were plenty of studies on specific measures of clinical symptoms, like depression, or emotional states like happiness or anxiety. Researchers had tracked objective markers of health, like blood pressure or sleep quality as well as were how economic conditions influence health.
But while these measures captured specific slices of both the problems and joys of life, VanderWeele felt they missed a holistic picture of what humans really seek, especially the need for meaning and purpose in life.
Since that first jo‚Ä¶

entry.title: Tracking US Migrant Detention Data: What Journalists Need to Understand
entry.summary: The US government's detained immigrant population flatlined in April, but there's more to the numbers than meets the eye. Here's what journalists need to know about the data.

entry.title: The life of Lexington, America‚Äôs greatest racehorse
entry.summary:
‚ÄúBest Time ever Made‚Äù declared the headline in the Louisville Daily Courier on April 4, 1855. Two days earlier, at a racecourse in New Orleans, a champion thoroughbred named Lexington had run four miles in seven minutes, 19 and three-quarter seconds, smashing the previous record by more than six seconds.
Lexington‚Äôs blazing speed record would stand unmatched for 20 years. But a severe infection had left the stallion blind in one eye and nearly so in the other. No longer able to race, he was sent to a stud farm, where he earned even greater renown.
‚ÄúLexington sired a powerful lineage filled with champions today,‚Äù says Kim Wickens, author of a forthcoming book on the legendary racehorse. ‚ÄúHe was the most dominant horse of his day and passed those genes down to a phenomenal line‚Ä¶

entry.title: 9 reasons to look up to the night sky this May
entry.summary:
May‚Äôs night sky is filled with entertainment for stargazers, whether you‚Äôre interested in observing planets, meteors, the moon, or even globular clusters. Grab your binoculars, set up your telescope, and get outside‚Äîhere‚Äôs what to look for in the cosmos throughout the month.
Just after sunset, look to the west to spot a celestial ‚Äúswarm.‚Äù The stars of the Beehive Cluster (Messier 44) will appear to buzz just below the crescent moon. Take a closer look, and you might notice one of the ‚Äúbees‚Äù has a reddish hue‚Äîthat‚Äôs Mars joining the fun.
(Here are five famous constellations that (almost) anyone can find.)
The Beehive cluster, located about 577 light-years away, contains more than a thousand stars. While some can be seen with the naked eye, the cluster‚Äôs dazzling display is ‚Ä¶

The definitive list of running shoes for every kind of runner, according to pros
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. Running is often referred to as one of the most accessible forms of exercise‚Äîall you need is a good pair of shoes. But many runners will tell you not to skimp on those shoes. Your running shoes could be the key to your physical and mental breakthroughs. Or they could be the reason you spend the next week, months, or even years with an unshakeable injury.¬†
I‚Äôve been an avid runner since my high school cross country days in the late ‚Äô90s. For a decad‚Ä¶

entry.title: Jet lag doesn‚Äôt have to ruin your trip. Here‚Äôs what to do
entry.summary:
Hop a plane across several time zones, and you may end up with what scientists call circadian dysrhythmia (aka jet lag). It‚Äôs a temporary sleep disorder where your body‚Äôs internal clock isn‚Äôt in sync with the time cues in your destination‚Äîdaylight, dark of night, mealtimes.
It‚Äôs also why you might doze off at lunch on your first day in London or be unable to get to sleep the first couple of nights of a vacation to Japan. ‚ÄúWe have a natural rhythm to our bodies, and it‚Äôs pretty well set,‚Äù says Vivek Jain, director of the George Washington University‚Äôs Center for Sleep Disorders.
But jet lag doesn‚Äôt have to wreck your trip. ‚ÄúIf you plan for it, you can do most of your acclimatizing to your destination a few days in advance,‚Äù says W. Chris Winter, neurologist and author of The Sleep‚Ä¶

entry.title: Ho Chi Minh City is a food-lover's paradise. Here's where to eat
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
I‚Äôm on the back of a Vespa, on my way to meet a gangster. Not that I know it yet. Night has descended and rain is slapping the tarmac with a fervent drumming. We‚Äôre soaked to the bone as we pull up outside a restaurant called Oc Loan on a small side street in Ho Chi Minh City. Water troughs are set out like street stalls, displaying snails bigger than my fist, plump clams and glistening river prawns. Presiding over them is a man in ripped denim shorts and flip-flops, weighed down by thick gold chains, knuckle dusters and gigantic cuffs. Needless to say, he‚Äôs not the ma√Ætre d‚Äô I‚Äôd been expecting.
Inspired by Michelin‚Äôs first restaurant guide to Ho Chi Minh, published in 2023, I‚Äôm taking a deep dive into the city‚Äôs e‚Ä¶

entry.title: Plague of rats and insects provide latest challenge for war-shattered Gazans
entry.summary: After suffering almost 18 months of deadly bombardment, displacement and lack of access to basic services, the embattled people of Gaza face yet another challenge: the threat of insects and rodents.

Meanwhile, the humanitarian crisis in Gaza deepens, with reports from the UN Palestine refugee relief agency (UNRWA) that children are "going to bed starving" amid the two-month Israeli aid blockade and continuing bombardment. entry.title: What the biggest flood on Earth looked like
entry.summary:
Six million years ago, the Mediterranean Sea wasn‚Äôt nearly as picturesque as it is today. It was barely even a sea; tectonic activity had raised a mountain range in the Strait of Gibraltar, cutting off the Mediterranean from the Atlantic. Without a constant inflow of water the sea evaporated under the baking sun, and all that remained were a few scattered, briny lakes surrounded by mile after mile of salt and gypsum. Today, scientists call this the Messinian Salinity Crisis: in the dying days of the Miocene epoch, most of the Mediterranean died.¬†
But if, on a certain day about 5.3 million years ago, you happened to go for a stroll along that mountain range, you might have discovered something odd: a trickle of water, making its way down one of the mountains from the Atlantic ocean bey‚Ä¶

entry.title: Australia has an absurdly huge feral camel problem
entry.summary:
Jack Carmody has built¬†a sizable YouTube following by showing his viewers what it takes to run a cattle station in the Australian outback‚Äîthe rugged work of mending troughs, reinforcing fences, and shooting trespassers. Feral horses and donkeys, that is, and one particularly destructive invasive species: camels. Introduced in the 19th century to help colonists survey the country‚Äôs vast interior, the creatures are now wreaking havoc across the outback and decimating the Carmody family‚Äôs ranch property, or what Australians call a cattle station. At more than 1,500 square miles, the property‚ÄîPrenti Downs‚Äîis the size of Rhode Island, so there‚Äôs plenty of work to be done, and in this modern internet age, there‚Äôs plenty of content to be created.¬†¬†
On Carmody‚Äôs channel, Jack Out The Back, no‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why the Kentucky Derby is a 151-year-old celebration of hats
entry.summary:
Ladies show off their Derby hats before the 150th running of the Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs in Louisville, Kentucky. The Kentucky Derby is the longest continuously-held sporting event in American history. America's longest running sports event comes with a distinctive sartorial tradition.
Although horses may be the stars of the Kentucky Derby, hats take center stage at the 151-year old horse race in the American heartland.
In Kentucky, hats‚Äîthe wilder the better‚Äîare central to the annual spring ritual, the ‚Äúrun for the roses.‚Äù On the first Saturday of May, horse-racing fans gather at Churchill Downs to watch the ‚Äúmost exciting two minutes in sports.‚Äù
Big, bold, and steeped in tradition ‚Äî here's everything you need to know about the history of hats at the Kentucky D‚Ä¶

entry.title: Anxious about flying? These calming products may help.
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*¬†
Travel can be exhilarating, but with so many moving parts and unpredictable factors, it can also be a major source of stress and anxiety. Navigating unfamiliar airports, managing time zone shifts, and adjusting to new surroundings take its toll. As a longtime travel writer, I‚Äôve tested plenty of tools to help manage my nerves.¬†¬†
To find the best travel gear for anxiety, I spoke with seasoned travelers and mental health professionals for their advic‚Ä¶

entry.title: This Alpine spa town has been popular for centuries‚Äîhere's why
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Morning light creeps over central Austria‚Äôs Hohe Tauern Alps, spotlighting summits one by one. As our yoga group launches into asanas, the valley below is bathed gold. There can be few lovelier spots to practise sun salutations than here, on a platform high in the forest of Bad Gastein, with a ringside seat of the mountains and within earshot of the town‚Äôs waterfall. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a magical place,‚Äù says Annette S√∂hnlein, smiling as radiant as the new day.
She‚Äôs leading a class at Haus Hirt, the Alpine-chic lodge where I‚Äôm staying for the week. Once a refuge for writers like Stefan Zweig and Thomas Mann, the 1920s building was redesigned in 2000, with contemporary art and rooms designed to frame the view. ‚ÄúHere in the embra‚Ä¶

entry.title: UN warns of $4 trillion shortfall threatening global development goals
entry.summary: Facing a staggering $4 trillion annual financing gap for development and mounting trade wars, top UN officials on Monday called for urgent action to rescue the Sustainable Development Goals and revive international cooperation.

entry.title: One in four female genital mutilation cases now carried out by health workers
entry.summary: Female genital mutilation (FGM) is becoming less common worldwide, but when it does occur, it is increasingly performed by professional healthcare workers, the UN World Health Organization (WHO) warned on Monday.

entry.title: How to plan the ultimate adventure along the Danube
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The Danube touches deep. Its landscapes are lyrical, its cities were built high and mighty by once-great empires, its history is as old as European civilisation itself. In 1866, Johann Strauss II extolled its beauty in The Blue Danube. And in 2025, on the 200th anniversary of the Austrian composer‚Äôs birth, his ever-popular waltz still captures the sprightly soul of the river, which flows from the Black Forest in Germany to the Black Sea in Romania and Ukraine. Whether seen in the mist of winter or summer‚Äôs first light, there‚Äôs poetry in these waters.
But where to begin? Many tours zoom in on the classic sights necklacing the Upper Danube between Germany and Hungary. The knockout is the 24-mile Wachau Valley in Uppe‚Ä¶

entry.title: There's a peaceful side to Bangkok‚Äîif you know where to look
entry.summary:
Find peace within this energetic city by stepping in any of the Buddhist temples like Wat Arun. Thailand‚Äôs capital city is a sensory overload, but between the tuk-tuk-packed streets and steamy markets there‚Äôs a serene, silent side to be found ‚Äî and it‚Äôs now easier to experience thanks to electric boat tours.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Captain Tai is the embodiment of Zen. He hops onto the deck of his royal-blue wooden boat, twiddles a few switches and we glide away from the canal bank in silence. Around us in the neighbourhoods that stem from the western banks of the Chao Phraya River, longtail boat owners race along the water, engines roaring, faces crumpled in scowls. But Captain Tai? Smiling.
Welcome to an entirely new version o‚Ä¶

entry.title: This Tuscan region is perfect for multi-generational vacations
entry.summary:
These naturally occurring hot springs were regarded as a gift from the gods by the Romans and Etruscans. Medieval hilltop towns, an unspoilt coastline and steamy hot springs make the Maremma region ideal for multi-generational holidays.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Southern Tuscany offers a quieter, more authentic escape to big-hitters such as Lucca and Siena, with a landscape defined by rolling vineyards, medieval hilltop towns and an unspoilt coastline. The Maremma region is an ideal base for multi-generational stays, and yet it‚Äôs still easily accessible from Florence to the north and Rome to the south in about two hours by car. Whether you seek luxury, adventure or relaxation, this pocket of Southern Tuscany delivers an unforgettable ex‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why the Faroe Islands should be your next road trip destination
entry.summary:
M√∫lafossur waterfall in G√°sadalur is one of the Faroe Islands‚Äô most famous natural wonders. Drive the Faroe Islands‚Äô scenic byways to get lost amid the clouds, witness waterfalls blowing themselves inside out and find a sense of solitude certain to leave you craving more.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The weather is famously fickle in the Faroe Islands. In the mountains, roads vanish into fog within seconds; by the sea, winds howl with such force that coastal waterfalls are sent streaming skywards. Haircuts take on an unintentional punk-rock edge. But on the afternoon of my arrival, the skies are a rare, perfect blue. Everything shines.
It‚Äôs early spring and, through my windscreen, the northern light is giving the ocean an ever-variega‚Ä¶

entry.title: Gaza: UN official warns of 'assault on dignity' as blockade cripples humanitarian response
entry.summary: The coming days in Gaza are set to be critical, the UN warned on Saturday, as humanitarian operations are severely curtailed amid an intensifying blockade, escalating violence, and soaring humanitarian needs.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: 7 ways to see the best of Greece's Peloponnese
entry.summary:
Myth has it that Voidokilia Beach is Homer's 'sandy Pylos', where Telemachus was welcomed by King Nestor when searching for Odysseus. A sleepy peninsula west of Athens, the Peloponnese offers uniquely Greek experiences ranging from visits to olive farms, boat trips into long-lost caves, rickety old train rides and mountain farm stays.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).¬†
The southernmost part of mainland Greece is the image of the country that many travellers hold in their heads. Home to ancient sites that speak of myths and legends, and a coastline sprinkled with pretty villages and white-sand beaches, it has all the appeal of Greece‚Äôs islands but few of their crowds. But there are plenty of other reasons to plan a trip, too, from staying on an ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Rome is teeming with mysterious papal crypts filled with secrets
entry.summary:
Remains of a sprawling necropolis (‚Äúcity of the dead‚Äù) hidden under St. Peter‚Äôs Basilica were discovered during excavations that began in the 1930s. The ancient Roman burial ground had been untouched for some 1,600 years and lies at depths of as much as 35 feet beneath a network of underground passageways called the Vatican Grottoes. The earthly remains of most of history‚Äôs 266 popes (plus some European royals) are buried in Rome‚Äîin dozens of catacombs and cemeteries in, under, and around the city.
Rome may be the Eternal City, but popes are mere mortal men. The earthly remains of most of history‚Äôs 266 popes over the past¬†1,961 years are buried in Rome, in dozens of crypts, catacombs, and cemeteries in, under, and around the city.
The very first was Peter,¬†who began his life a‚Ä¶

entry.title: Managing Editor
entry.summary: Frontier Myanmar is seeking a Managing Editor to help lead our newsroom. The successful candidate will work with a team of award-winning journalists and together with other senior editors oversee the production of accurate, in-depth reports on a fast-developing situation in Myanmar. Duties will include commissioning and editing stories, managing reporters and liaising with freelancers [‚Ä¶]

entry.title: Why Menorca's capital is one of Spain's most underrated cities
entry.summary:
Stretching for eight miles, Mah√≥n's harbour remains the heart of the city alongside the Old Town, which gazes down from a rocky outcrop. The capital of the quiet Balearic island of Menorca offers an atmospheric old town, thriving food scene and tranquil beaches.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
As Spanish cities go, Mahon is relatively little known to travellers, despite its tumultous history. The port city on Menorca‚Äôs southeast coast has been at the centre of centuries of conflict, with everyone from the Moors to the Ottomans and French taking control of its natural harbour, the second largest in the world. But it was the British who left their mark, ruling from the early 18th to the early 19th century, leaving a series of military building‚Ä¶

entry.title: Sudan situation ‚Äòabsolutely devastating‚Äô as UN ramps up food aid
entry.summary: The situation in western Sudan is ‚Äúshocking‚Äù and people in the capital, Khartoum face ‚Äúabsolutely devastating‚Äù conditions according to a senior UN official in the African country.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN Security Council condemns Jammu and Kashmir terror attack
entry.summary: The UN Security Council has strongly condemned the deadly terrorist attack in Jammu and Kashmir on Tuesday that killed at least 26 tourists and left many more injured, calling for accountability and international cooperation to bring the perpetrators to justice.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Destitution and disease stalk Myanmar‚Äôs quake survivors
entry.summary: One month since Myanmar‚Äôs earthquake disaster, tens of thousands of survivors still live in makeshift tents with little to protect them from pre-monsoon storms and mosquitoes.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: From border control to belonging: How host communities gain from empowering refugees
entry.summary: With humanitarian aid in decline, the international community must shift its focus from short-term relief efforts to inclusive policies that support both refugees and host communities.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Security Council debates precarious path forward for a new Syria
entry.summary: Syria is undergoing a rocky transition after years of conflict and authoritarian rule. Despite tentative political progress, ongoing violence, deepening economic hardship and a worsening humanitarian crisis highlight the urgent and continued need for international support.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Ukraine: Continued Russian assaults drive civilians from frontline communities
entry.summary: As Ukrainian cities struggle to recover from this week‚Äôs deadly missile and drone strikes, frontline areas remain under relentless attack, the UN refugee agency (UNHCR) reported on Friday, warning of ongoing displacement and deepening humanitarian needs.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: WFP runs out of food stocks in Gaza
entry.summary: The World Food Programme (WFP) has run out of food in the Gaza Strip as Israel continues to block the entry of all humanitarian aid into the enclave, home to over two million people.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: DR Congo crisis forces refugees to swim for their lives to Burundi
entry.summary: The number of desperate refugees fleeing conflict in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) and seeking safety in Burundi continues to rise, placing immense pressure on aid agencies struggling to cope with an escalating crisis amid dwindling resources.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: The UK‚Äôs beach towns are bouncing back‚Äîhere are 7 of the best
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
At the turn of the century, a range of micro and macro factors, from whittled-down transport links to the availability of cheap foreign holidays, combined to lay waste to Britain‚Äôs seaside towns. Precious few were to escape the ruinous effects of this retreat of the economic tide.
Fast forward to 2025, however, and it‚Äôs a very different picture. Just as the decline stemmed from multiple factors, the resurgence is driven by a complex web of influences. The cost-of-living crisis, flight scepticism and the lure of the great outdoors are all playing a part. So too is the staycation boom, which was accelerated by the pandemic.¬†
Sure, only the most misty-eyed nostalgist could fail to spot boarded-up shops and buildi‚Ä¶

entry.title: Whales could one day defend themselves in court‚Äîand in their own words
entry.summary:
Two summers ago, in the turquoise waters off the coast of a small Caribbean island called Dominica, a sperm whale named Rounder began to give birth. Eleven members of her clan slowly gathered around to support her, converging from miles away in their home waters. They called to one another in choruses of Morse code-like clicks as they waited for the baby to arrive and in the hours that followed, when they held the calf above water so that she could breathe, only lowering her when her fins finished unfurling. Soon after, they departed.
Scientists are developing innovations in recording and analyzing sperm whale communications that could someday make it possible to understand at least some of what whales say to each other in these extraordinary moments. People might translate what they ‚Ä¶

entry.title: How female bonobos team up to gain power over males
entry.summary:
Why do female bonobos often outrank males, especially when the opposite is true for most social mammals, like their close relative the chimpanzee?¬†
That‚Äôs the question¬†Martin Surbeck¬†and his colleagues wanted to answer. And after monitoring six communities of bonobos in the Democratic Republic of the Congo for nearly three decades, they have arrived at a conclusion.¬†
By banding together in coalitions‚Äîmeaning groups of two or more animals, but usually three to five‚Äîfemale bonobos both reduce the danger posed by males and catapult themselves into positions of influence. Fully 85 percent of cases of female coalitionary aggression were directed at males, which also tend to be larger than females.
‚ÄúWe have found what everybody already knows‚Äîthat when you work together, you‚Äôre‚Ä¶

entry.title: How archaeologists found one of the oldest cities on earth
entry.summary:
Archaeologists excavate the site of the ancient Sumerian city of Eridu, near Basra in southern Iraq, in 2022. Excavations on unpromising mounds in the Iraqi desert revealed Sumer‚Äôs earliest city. Surviving relics and a rebuilt temple have given experts more clues about the ancient metropolis of Eridu.
Buried in the Mesopotamian desert, undisturbed for over two millennia lay a hidden key to understanding one of the world‚Äôs oldest known civilizations.
In 1854 British official John George Taylor was sent on an excavation mission to the desert of southern Iraq by the British consul general in Baghdad. Taylor, an agent of the East India Company and British vice-consul at Basra, was commissioned with investigating a remote site called Tell Abu Shahrain, where there was a series ‚Ä¶

entry.title: This camouflaged critter wears severed insect body parts like a coat
entry.summary:
It‚Äôs Halloween every day for the bone collector caterpillar. The moth larva decorates its drag-along dwelling with scavenged body parts from dead insects. This ghastly getup may allow the creatures to live alongside spiders without being detected.
These pill-sized caterpillars look like piles of parts‚Äîan ant head here, fly legs and wings there, a stuck-on weevil head, and jettisoned spider legs jutting out all over. Beneath this constructed case is a ‚Äúgeneric white gushy body,‚Äù says Daniel Rubinoff, an entomologist at the University of Hawai ªi at MƒÅnoa. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs gross at one level, but it‚Äôs also kind of adorable. They‚Äôre cruising around like, ‚ÄòOh, this looks delicious. I‚Äôll eat some of this and then put the rest on my back.‚Äô‚Äù undefinedWhen studying bone collector caterpillars in the‚Ä¶

entry.title: 7 hotels that support traditional Japanese crafts
entry.summary:
In Japan, a combination of lifestyle changes, urbanization, and a shrinking population is threatening the preservation of many of the traditional crafts for which the country is known. But over recent years, craft-focused hotels have emerged as tools to support artisans‚Äô livelihoods while providing travelers with one-of-a-kind experiences.
‚ÄúThe sales of traditional Japanese crafts peaked in 1975 and have been on a continuous decline ever since, dropping to one-fifth of their peak, while the number of artisans has decreased to one-third,‚Äù says Tomotsugu Yamakawa, president of Bed and Craft in Toyama Prefecture‚Äôs small town of Inami, where around 150 people out of a population of 8,000 are woodcarvers.
‚ÄúGiven this situation, I wondered if tourism could be a means to revitalize the ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Scientists find 113-million-year-old ‚Äòhell ant‚Äô with scythe jaws
entry.summary:
The oldest ant fossil ever discovered had forward-facing scythe-like jaws it used to hunt, according to a new study in Current Biology.¬†
Now the oldest ant specimen known to science, the roughly half-inch-long¬†113-million-year-old impression preserved in limestone was found in northeastern Brazil,¬†and is a new genus belonging to the ‚Äúhell ant‚Äù subfamily Haidomyrmecinae. Hell ants only lived during the Cretaceous period, which ended 66 million years ago.¬†
Modern ants are one of the most dominant animal groups on Earth, with over 17,000 ant species found throughout every continent except Antarctica. Scientists think ants diverged from the evolutionary lineage that wasps originated from, then took on a more ant-like form during the Cretaceous period with a smaller thorax and a speci‚Ä¶

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: About Pew Research Center‚Äôs Spring 2024 Global Attitudes Survey Results for the survey are based on telephone, face-to-face and online interviews conducted under the direction of Gallup, Langer Research Associates, Social Research Centre and Verian. The results are based on national samples, unless otherwise noted. Here are more details about our international survey methodology and [‚Ä¶] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

Jacob Poushter, Associate Director, Global Attitudes ResearchMaria Smerkovich, Research AssociateMoira Fagan, Research AssociateAndrew Prozorovsky, Research Assistant Dorene Asare-Marfo, Senior Panel ManagerPeter Bell, Associate Director, Design and ProductionJanakee Chavda, Associate Digital ProducerLaura Clancy, Research AnalystRachel Drian, Associate Director, CommunicationsJonathan Evans, [‚Ä¶] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Appendix: Economic categorization of high- and middle-income countries
entry.summary: For this report, we grouped countries into high-income and middle-income categories based on definitions from the World Bank. The post Appendix: Economic categorization of high- and middle-income countries appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 4. Freedom gaps
entry.summary: In many countries, the share rating free press or speech as important is larger than the share saying they actually have that freedom. The post 4. Freedom gaps appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. How people rate press, speech and internet freedoms in their country
entry.summary: A median of 31% across 35 countries say they're completely free to speak without censorship, and 28% say their media are completely free to report the news. The post 3. How people rate press, speech and internet freedoms in their country appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Importance of press freedom, free speech and freedom on the internet
entry.summary: Across 35 countries, most people rate press, speech and internet freedoms as important, but the shares who call these very important range somewhat. The post 2. Importance of press freedom, free speech and freedom on the internet appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Widespread global public concern about made-up news
entry.summary: A median of 59% across 35 countries see made-up news as a very big problem. The post 1. Widespread global public concern about made-up news appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Free Expression Seen as Important Globally, but Not Everyone Thinks Their Country Has Press, Speech and Internet Freedoms
entry.summary: Across 35 countries, there are some disconnects between how people rate the importance of free expression and how free they feel they actually are. The post Free Expression Seen as Important Globally, but Not Everyone Thinks Their Country Has Press, Speech and Internet Freedoms appeared first on Pew Research Center.

AI agents use E2B to manage a virtual computerÔºå run code and serve results back to the users (AI Êô∫ËÉΩ‰Ωì‰ΩøÁî® E2B ÁÆ°ÁêÜËôöÊãüËÆ°ÁÆóÊú∫„ÄÅËøêË°å‰ª£Á†ÅÂπ∂Â∞ÜÁªìÊûúËøîÂõûÁªôÁî®Êà∑) The amount of time each sandbox ran for went up >10x from 2024 to 2025Ôºå mostly driven by new long-running agents experiences like Manus that their customers are building (ÊØè‰∏™Ê≤ôÁÆ±ÁöÑËøêË°åÊó∂Èó¥‰ªé 2024 Âπ¥Âà∞ 2025 Âπ¥Â¢ûÂä†‰∫Ü 10 ÂÄç‰ª•‰∏äÔºåËøô‰∏ªË¶ÅÊòØÁî±‰∫éÂÉè Manus ËøôÊ†∑Êñ∞ÁöÑÈïøÊúüËøêË°åÊô∫ËÉΩ‰Ωì‰ΩìÈ™åÊé®Âä®ÁöÑÔºå‰ªñ‰ª¨ÁöÑÂÆ¢Êà∑Ê≠£Âú®ÊûÑÂª∫Ëøô‰∫õ‰ΩìÈ™å) It's a good idea to stop thinking about the sandbox just for code interpreting and more about like a runtimeÔºå code runtime for the LLM or the agent. (ÊúÄÂ•Ω‰∏çË¶ÅÂÜçÂ∞ÜÊ≤ôÁÆ±‰ªÖ‰ªÖËßÜ‰∏∫‰ª£Á†ÅËß£ÈáäÂô®ÔºåËÄåÊõ¥Â§öÂú∞Â∞ÜÂÖ∂ËßÜ‰∏∫ LLM ÊàñÊô∫ËÉΩ‰ΩìÁöÑËøêË°åÊó∂„ÄÅ‰ª£Á†ÅËøêË°åÊó∂) üìä ÊñáÁ´†‰ø°ÊÅØ

entry.title: See Australia's wild beauty and dark history on this Great Walk
entry.summary:
Australia has a new Great Walk on Flinders Island that provides hikers with a once-in-a-lifetime experience to learn about the island‚Äôs Aboriginal and European history, wildlife, and spectacular scenery, including the views from Mount Strzelecki. Wildlife, wilderness, and culture collide on this multi-day walking experience on a little-known island in Tasmania.
The aquamarine water is so clear and warm it could be in the Caribbean, and the white silica beaches framed by granite boulders are reminiscent of the Seychelles. The giveaway is the tangerine lichen spattered on the rocks‚Äîa clear sign that this is the Australian island state of¬†Tasmania¬†(Lutruwita).¬†
But this isn‚Äôt the Bay of Fires (Larapuna), famed for the magnificent contrasting hues of its coastal landscape. I‚Äôm on ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Discover Greece‚Äôs historic wonders beyond the islands
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Greece is home to some of the world‚Äôs most extraordinary heritage sites. These range from ancient buildings ‚Äî such as the extraordinary monasteries of Meteora, perched high on sandstone pinnacles, and the Parthenon temple in Athens ‚Äî to the pretty, pastel-hued villages that line the coast. There are marvels of engineering, too, including the Corinth Canal, which connects the Ionian and Aegean Seas, and the fortified island town of Monemvasia, which seems to tumble down the cliffs straight to the sea.
Nothing bellows ‚ÄòAncient Greece‚Äô like the Parthenon, the crowning glory of the hilltop Acropolis citadel and visible all over Athens. The temple was built by hand from white marble in 447 BCE to give thanks to Athena‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to plan the ultimate coastal Greece road trip
entry.summary:
Panagia Chapel sits on a small island off the coast of Parga. Take a gently paced coastal road trip from Kalamata in the southern Peloponnese to Parga in Epirus to experience ancient sites, fishing villages and beaches lapped by the Ionian Sea.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
A slow road trip along mainland Greece‚Äôs coastline takes you from one idyllic site to another, from whitewashed villages tucked alongside sea fortresses to quiet beaches just a short drive from ancient temples. There are plenty of opportunities to stop off for a seafood lunch and a quick swim, and chances to end each day with a sundowner overlooking the sea.
Start in Kalamata in the southern Peloponnese, where Greece dips its toes into the gulf linking the Ionian ‚Ä¶

entry.title: There's a new clue to solve the universe's biggest mystery
entry.summary:
If you had asked me a year ago about the most likely ultimate fate of the universe, I would have been able to answer immediately. As a cosmologist, I‚Äôve spent a lot of time thinking about the end of the universe‚ÄîI even wrote a book on the topic. We know the universe is expanding, and that expansion is speeding up. In the far distant future, this accelerating expansion will empty out the cosmos until there‚Äôs essentially nothing left. Stars burn out, matter decays, black holes evaporate, and eventually nothing is left but a few stray particles of light diffusing away the waste heat of all creation. This scenario is sometimes called the ‚Äúheat death‚Äù or the ‚Äúbig freeze‚Äù, and it‚Äôs a straightforward consequence of our best working theory for how the universe behaves.

entry.title: Why pho tastes different depending on where you are
entry.summary:
In the buzzing matrix of Hanoi‚Äôs old quarter sits Ph·ªü Th√¨n, one of 700-or-so pho restaurants that speckle this thousand-year-old city. Ph·ªü Th√¨n is practically outfitted with stainless steel tables, embellished by jars and shakers, over wastebaskets for the innumerable spent lime rinds and napkins requisite for enjoying Vietnam‚Äôs beloved national dish. Beneath the whirr of fans and clank of lids, diners pore over their bowls of ph·ªü b√≤ (beef pho), which owner Nguy·ªÖn Tr·ªçng Th√¨n has been serving here since 1979.‚ÄØ¬†
Nguy·ªÖn opened Ph·ªü Th√¨n in the scarce years following the Vietnam War, hoping it would always enable him to feed his newborn son. A fiercely proud Hanoian from a family that has resided in this very neighborhood for 10 generations, Nguy·ªÖn developed his pho recipe, slightly smoky ‚Ä¶

entry.title: How Scotland is reviving an ancient pagan fire ritual
entry.summary:
Each spring, on the night of April 30, thousands gather on Edinburgh‚Äôs Calton Hill to welcome the return of summer‚Äîwith fire. Performers dressed in dramatic costumes move through the crowd, reenacting ancient rituals to drums and chants echoing across the city.
The crowd‚Äîlocals and tourists alike‚Äîcomes for the Beltane Fire Festival, Britain‚Äôs largest modern celebration of an ancient that honors fire, fertility, and the changing season. Revived in 1988 by a group of artists and volunteers, the festival has grown into a high-energy spectacle rooted in tradition but shaped by modern values.
So how did a nearly forgotten pagan fire ritual become one of Scotland‚Äôs most iconic annual events?
Beltane (pronounced BEL-tayn) is one of eight seasonal festivals in the Celtic calendar,‚Ä¶

entry.title: What to know about stage 0 cancer‚Äîand why it‚Äôs rarely diagnosed
entry.summary:
While most of us have heard of stage I, II, and III cancer‚Äîand especially the grimmest stage IV‚Äîmany people don't know there's also an earlier stage of cancer known as stage 0.
Until recently, that included Tina Knowles, the mother of singer Beyonce, who revealed a breast cancer diagnosis in her new memoir. In an¬†interview¬†about the importance of getting screened early and often for cancer she said, "I didn't know that there was a stage 0. I could have caught this at stage 0 if I had not missed my mammogram."¬†¬†
(When should you get screened for breast cancer‚Äîand how often?)
It‚Äôs unsurprising that Knowles didn‚Äôt know about stage 0 as it isn‚Äôt as commonly diagnosed as the other stages of cancer. It also isn‚Äôt detectable for many types of cancer and often goes by a different na‚Ä¶

entry.title: This ancient croc was bigger than most dinosaurs
entry.summary: The giant crocodilian Deinosuchus was a top predator in wetlands habitats of the late Cretaceous. Here Deinosuchus hatcheri, a species from a rock formation in what is now Utah, chows down on a duck-billed dinosaur called Rhinorex condrupus. The prehistoric crocodile relative may have tolerated both freshwater and saltwater habitats, allowing it to conquer North American coasts in the Cretaceous. Around 75 million years ago, North America‚Äôs largest and most formidable carnivore was not a dinosaur‚Äîbut a croc. Deinosuchus, the ‚Äúterrible crocodile‚Äù in Greek, could reach more than 35 feet in length and weigh over five tons. Bite marks on bones leave no doubt that the immense reptile caught and ate dinosaurs. How Deinosuchus became such a large and widespread p‚Ä¶

entry.title: Heading to Rome? Here are 5 towns near the Eternal City you can't miss.
entry.summary:
Travelers visiting Rome should consider visiting nearby lesser-known towns like Tivoli to explore nature, art, and history without the crowds. Had enough of the crowds? Once you‚Äôve seen Rome, consider a day trip to these lesser known but no less beautiful towns for sunbathing, medieval charm, and fairy-tale gardens.
As one of the most popular tourist destinations in the world, Rome welcomes hordes of tourists every day. However, 2025 is the Holy Year of the Catholic Church, and the amalgamation of¬†35 million pilgrims¬†visiting the Eternal City for the Jubilee might make your Roman holiday more hell than heaven if you don‚Äôt plan ahead. Although the local administration made many¬†infrastructure renovations, Rome will still be overpopulated ‚Äì not to mention plagued by price inflation f‚Ä¶

It may not seem like a necessity, but a comfy cozy travel blanket can make a big difference on trips.¬†¬†
‚ÄúSome of us may sleep very well when we travel, while others may struggle,‚Äù says sleep expert Rebecca Robbins, an assistant professor in medicine at Harvard Medical School and an associate scientist at the Brigham and Women‚Äôs Hospital. ‚ÄúBringing elements that are cozy and comforting, such as a blanket, eye mask, or other elements, can remind you o‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why heart attacks are rising in young adults
entry.summary:
Despite declines among older adults, the proportion of heart attacks among younger adults is increasing across the globe‚Äîan alarming trend that many doctors who spoke to National Geographic consider a public health emergency. (Young adults are loosely defined as those between 20 to 50 years old.)
Mounting evidence also shows that more young adults are experiencing all kinds of heart problems compared to decades past, and that worsening lifestyle habits‚Äînamely, poor diet and lack of exercise‚Äîare to blame. And some research suggests that COVID infections are adding insult to injury.
(It's not just heart attacks. Colon cancer is rising among young adults.)
Recent events have underscored these concerns. In 2024, a healthy 38-year-old made headlines after he had a heart attack an‚Ä¶

entry.title: Will a woman finally break the 4-minute mile?
entry.summary:
Eldoret, Kenya‚ÄúWatch her,‚Äù says the man with the stopwatch, nodding toward the far end of the sun-cracked track. It‚Äôs a Saturday morning in March at the dilapidated stadium in the city of Eldoret, high above the Great Rift Valley in western Kenya. I follow the man‚Äôs gaze to where the greatest middle-distance runner of all time rounds the last turn, training for the impossible.¬†¬†
It‚Äôs hard to gauge the speed of 31-year-old Faith Kipyegon. She is too smooth. Though she runs nearly at a sprint, her arms and legs slide forward and back with a liquid ease. Her face shows so little strain she might be a jogger out for a brisk trot around Central Park. Only her eyes betray her effort. They seem not to notice the spalling concrete of the never finished stadium, the weeds that grow in its gran‚Ä¶

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 167 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Center‚Äôs nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted from April 7 to April 13, 2025. A total of 3,589 panelists responded out of 4,036 who were sampled, [‚Ä¶] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals: Research team Jocelyn Kiley, Director, Political ResearchHannah Hartig, Senior ResearcherBaxter Oliphant, Senior ResearcherGabe Borelli, Research AssociateAndrew Daniller, Research AssociateAndy Cerda, Research AnalystJoseph Copeland, Research AnalystTed Van Green, Research Analyst Shanay Gracia, Research Assistant Communications and editorial Nida Asheer, Senior [‚Ä¶] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 4. Economic ratings and concerns
entry.summary: About a quarter (23%) of Americans say the economy is in excellent or good shape, and 45% expect conditions to be worse a year from now. The post 4. Economic ratings and concerns appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 5. Views of Congress, parties and courts
entry.summary: Over nine-in-ten Americans say it's important that federal judges are fair and impartial in their rulings, but far fewer have confidence they actually are. The post 5. Views of Congress, parties and courts appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Tariffs, DEI and cuts to government: Views of Trump‚Äôs key actions
entry.summary: More Americans disapprove than approve of the Trump administration's government cuts, tariffs increases and ending of federal DEI policies. The post 3. Tariffs, DEI and cuts to government: Views of Trump‚Äôs key actions appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Views of how the Trump administration governs
entry.summary: About half of Americans say Trump is doing to much by executive order, and most say his administration must follow federal court rulings. The post 2. Views of how the Trump administration governs appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Evaluations of Trump: Job approval and confidence on issues
entry.summary: Trump's job approval is down since February, especially among his less strong supporters and 2024 nonvoters. And fewer than half of Americans have confidence in Trump to handle most issues. The post 1. Evaluations of Trump: Job approval and confidence on issues appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Trump‚Äôs Job Rating Drops, Key Policies Draw Majority Disapproval as He Nears 100 Days
entry.summary: Trump's approval rating stands at 40%, and Americans mostly disapprove of his tariffs and government cuts. The post Trump‚Äôs Job Rating Drops, Key Policies Draw Majority Disapproval as He Nears 100 Days appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Largely eradicated diseases at risk of returning due to budget cuts
entry.summary: Vaccines have saved around 150 million lives over the past 50 years, but that progress is now under threat.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Health, education, opportunity at stake, amid stubborn digital gender divide
entry.summary: As transformative technologies such as Artificial Intelligence continue to reshape the global economy, millions of women and girls remain excluded from the digital world ‚Äì denied not only access to opportunity, but also the chance to shape their own futures.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sexual violence systematically used as a weapon of war in the DR Congo
entry.summary: The ongoing conflict in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC) continues to have devastating consequences, particularly for women and children, who face an increased risk of conflict-related sexual violence.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Sewage, trash and disease overwhelm displaced communities in Gaza
entry.summary: Amid sweltering heat, raw sewage and overflowing trash, displaced families in southern Gaza are facing an escalating public health crisis as aid remains blocked and medical supplies dwindle.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: AI lightens the workload ‚Äì but risks remain, labour agency warns
entry.summary: Artificial intelligence, robotics, and digitalization are rapidly reshaping how we work ‚Äì but they‚Äôre a source of unexpected risks too.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World leaders rally for ‚Äòfull-speed‚Äô climate action ahead of COP30
entry.summary: At a high stakes virtual summit on Wednesday, UN Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres and Brazilian President Luiz In√°cio Lula da Silva brought together 17 national leaders from major economies and climate-vulnerable countries. The goal was to accelerate global climate ambition ahead of COP30, which will be hosted in Brazil.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Stopping child marriage is key to curbing deadly teen pregnancies: WHO
entry.summary: Teenage pregnancy remains the leading cause of death for girls aged 15 to 19, which countries could help prevent by allowing them to remain in school and ending child marriage, the UN World Health Organization (WHO) said on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.summary: DOGE is taking agency data in an effort to compile a master database‚Ä¶ Tags: DOGE, immigration, privacy, Wired

entry.title: Inside the Arizona city that's America's final frontier
entry.summary:
The Mission San Xavier del Bac dates back to the 1700s and depicts Tucson's Spanish-filled roots. The city of Tucson, Arizona, sits on America‚Äôs southern border, surrounded by the cactus-strewn landscapes of the Sonoran Desert. Its present-day creativity draws on its Native American and Mexican roots, Spanish colonial heritage and Wild West frontier days.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK). The desert is the greenest on the planet and sustains two of Arizona‚Äôs three wine regions. One, Sonoita, is home to the Los Milics Vineyards winery. The city, meanwhile, is a canvas for countless street artists, including London-based Fin DAC, whose mural Vergiss adorns the side of Charro Steak & Del Rey restaurant. The view through the sagua‚Ä¶

entry.title: The blackout that nearly broke NYC‚Äîand the logo that saved it
entry.summary:
During the 1977 blackout, fires broke out across New York City, exposing the depths of its financial and social crisis. In the aftermath, a simple logo helped reshape the city‚Äôs image. In 1977, with dozens of fires set daily and tourism in freefall, New York hired an artist to save the city. His infamous sketch in the back of a yellow cab became the most imitated logo in history‚Äîand cities are still copying it today.
In the summer of 1977, New York City was burning. A 25-hour blackout, triggered by lightning striking key transmission lines, led to widespread looting, riots, and more than a thousand fires.
That night alone, the fire department battled blazes across Harlem, Brooklyn, and the South Bronx, a shocking surge in a city already averaging four dozen fires a day. New Yo‚Ä¶

entry.title: Escape the crowds at the lower 48‚Äôs most remote national park
entry.summary:
At a time when record crowds are seeing visitors to some U.S. national parks asked to pre-book access, Isle Royale National Park, an archipelago of around 400 islands on western Lake Superior, is the very definition of off the beaten track.
Its main island is about 50 miles long and nine miles wide‚Äî19 times the size of Manhattan‚Äîand sees less than one percent of the average number of visitors to Yosemite National Park when it opens to the public on around April 15 every year.
As the least-visited national park in the continental U.S., Isle Royale National Park is only reachable by ferry, private boat or seaplane from mainland Michigan and Minnesota.
It‚Äôs a place where the only vehicles are canoes and kayaks, and moose, wolves, beavers and smaller animals are the sole year-ro‚Ä¶

entry.title: How ancient trash is protecting these coastal islands today
entry.summary:
On the barrier islands off the coast of Georgia,¬†around 585 square miles of salt marshes lie next to forests so dense with hardwoods and Spanish moss that sunshine can only filter through in slender rays.
‚ÄúThey‚Äôre almost otherworldly,‚Äù says Jacob Holland-Lulewicz, an archaeologist at Pennsylvania State University. To visitors, these islands can feel untouched.
Yet, recent research by Holland-Lulewicz and his colleagues shows how humans have significantly altered these barrier islands over millennia by discarding¬†millions of oyster shells, unintentionally creating deposits so substantial they now protect portions of the islands from today's rising sea levels.
‚ÄúThese ecosystems that we all enjoy and that we want to preserve are actually the result of thousands of years of indi‚Ä¶

entry.title: We thought Andean bears were mute‚Äîuntil they were heard mating
entry.summary:
New discoveries about the Andean bear language show that the species makes five distinct sounds during mating. Researchers have captured footage of these bears making a wide range of vocalizations during their most intimate moments‚Äîthe first time sounds of this kind have been documented in any bear species.
Until recently, the Andean bear‚Äîthe only species of bear in South America, easily recognized by the light-colored markings that frame its face like glasses‚Äîwas thought to be almost mute; there were only a few documented cases of vocal exchanges between mothers and cubs in captivity. But recently, deep in the Andes, camera traps captured something unexpected: During mating, this elusive creature becomes surprisingly expressive. It moans, growls, and purrs.
With this new info‚Ä¶

entry.title: Portable photo printers are one of our favorite travel gadgets
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*¬†
Digital photos may be convenient for travel, but there‚Äôs something special about holding a printed picture. Portable photo printers let you turn your favorite snapshots into instant keepsakes, no matter where you are.¬†¬†
‚ÄúI‚Äôve been journaling my whole life but started taking it more seriously in 2020 as a way to relive my adventures, and since then, I incorporate different creative elements into my journaling, including photography,‚Äù says Ayusha Aya‚Ä¶

entry.title: These are the best dishes to try in Kuala Lumpur
entry.summary:
The ebi katsu sando at Reka Bar consists of succulent prawn katsu between a soft, vibrant ube milk loaf. Innovative chefs are mixing traditional ingredients with modern techniques in Malaysia's capital.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).¬†¬†
The dining scene in Kuala Lumpur has long reflected Malaysia‚Äôs rich cultural tapestry, with traditional Malay, Chinese and Indian cuisines as staples. And now, the city is embracing culinary innovation, too. From elevated street food to avant-garde fine dining, chefs are pushing boundaries with fusion dishes and unique ingredients. Here are the best places to experience the Malaysian capital‚Äôs ever-evolving food landscape.
This dish epitomises chef Darren Teoh‚Äôs commitment to celebrating local, indigen‚Ä¶

entry.title: Lentils and peas are overlooked protein powerhouses
entry.summary:
Beans hog the nutritional spotlight in the kitchen and on TikTok, but their fellow legumes lentils and peas pack high nutritional punches, too. These foods are so full of protein, fiber, and antioxidants that the American diet should be brimming with them, according to a recent report by the U.S. government‚Äôs 2025 Dietary Guidelines Advisory Committee.
Various legumes are staples in Indian, Middle Eastern, and other cuisines but rare in classic American fare. ‚ÄúIt is embarrassing how few legumes people eat in the U.S.,‚Äù says Christopher Gardner, a nutrition scientist at Stanford University who helped author the new report. Even when people do eat them, he says, they lean towards the category‚Äôs most prominent member, beans.¬†
(Black beans, pinto, and cannellini are also nutritionall‚Ä¶

entry.title: ‚ÄòSharktopus‚Äô isn't alone‚Äîthese animals hitchhike on other animals.
entry.summary: A classic example of phoresy, the remora uses a modified fin that latches onto larger animals like a suction cup. Here three remoras (Remora brachyptera) ride a Chilean devil ray (Mobula tarapacana) off the coast of Santa Maria Island, Azores.  Cockroaches that catch a ride on ants. Grasshoppers that climb aboard sheep. Hitchhiking animals are more common than you think. Spend enough time in nature, and you will see some weird stuff‚Äîfrom orcas swimming around wearing salmon like hats to wombats pooping cubes. But when Rochelle Constantine saw a nine-foot-long mako shark jet past her research vessel in the Hauraki Gulf off New Zealand with a huge, orange octopus globbed onto its head, she knew she was witnessing something new.¬† ‚ÄúIt was jus‚Ä¶

entry.title: 10 eclectic, must-see museums in San Diego
entry.summary:
A visitor passes through the "Light Floor" art installation at the WNDR Museum in San Diego. To get a feel for the soul of San Diego, stop by these innovative museums found in Balboa Park and along the scenic coastline.
San Diego‚Äôs epicenter for arts and culture is Balboa Park. This 1,200-acre urban oasis is home to 18 museums (and dozens of gardens, attractions, and fun venues). Visit the traditional institutions here‚Äîor swing over to the¬†recently added¬†Comic-Con Museum.¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†
In case you didn‚Äôt know, Balboa Park shares a zip code with downtown San Diego, and the city‚Äôs urban core has its own set of eclectic offerings, like the nautical¬†USS Midway Museum¬†and¬†the Maritime Museum. With so many museums in the city, museophiles can pare down their options with this helpful list o‚Ä¶

entry.title: We planned the perfect day in San Diego for 3 types of travelers
entry.summary:
Travelers visiting San Diego can plan the perfect day trip to explore the city with three itineraries designed for families, adventurers, and culture enthusiasts. San Diego is known as the heart of SoCal surf culture, but there's more to this city than just beaches and sunny weather. Here‚Äôs how to explore the city‚Äôs intriguing history, impressive museums and vibrant neighborhoods.
While Spanish explorer Juan Rodriguez Cabrillo failed to find an all-water route‚Äîthe mythical ‚ÄúStrait of Anian‚Äù‚Äîacross North America in 1542, he did discover San Diego Bay, which he remarked was ‚Äúa very good port.‚Äù The Indigenous Kumeyaay people had already lived there for thousands of years. Cabrillo still claimed the land for Spain, beginning a tumultuous period where San Diego would be under Spanish, t‚Ä¶

entry.title: The brain has a secret survival trick to endure a marathon
entry.summary:
A marathon taxes more than just muscles‚Äîit pushes the brain to its metabolic limits. New research shows that during extreme endurance events, the brain may burn its own fat for fuel, revealing just how adaptable‚Äîand surprising‚Äîthe mind can be. A study of long-distance runners shows the brain‚Äôs remarkable ability to adapt‚Äîby burning its own fat.
Carlos Matute wasn‚Äôt looking for a scientific breakthrough when he laced up his shoes for a long run. But as the miles ticked by, the¬†neuroscientist¬†from the University of the Basque Country found himself chasing a persistent question: ‚ÄúHow do we make it to the finish line, being conscious, after having our energy stores depleted?‚Äù¬†
That curiosity led to a surprising possible answer. In¬†a recent study¬†in¬†Nature Metabolism, Matute found ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Here are 9 top-notch sun hats for travelers
entry.summary:
By clicking on the featured links, visitors will leave nationalgeographic.com and be directed to third-party e-commerce sites that operate under different terms and privacy policies. As a participant in multiple affiliate marketing programs, National Geographic will earn a commission for certain purchases. See full disclaimer below.*¬†
Every traveler knows sunscreen is essential for any trip. But experts also recommend supplementing lotions and creams with a good sun hat.¬†
The Skin Cancer Foundation says the overwhelming majority of skin cancers are caused by cells that first appear on the head and neck and recommends hats for extra protection. The best sun hats have wide brims, flaps to protect the ears and neck (especially for outdoor activities), tight weaving to block rays, a‚Ä¶

entry.title: Avoid crowds at the 10 least-visited U.S. national parks
entry.summary:
A camper gazes at the central Brooks Mountain Range, which includes East and West Maiden Peaks, Camel Peak, and Arrigetch Peaks‚Äîall found within the Alaska's Gates of the Arctic National Park and Preserve. Get off the beaten path at these under-the-radar wilderness areas.
Since its founding on August 25, 1916, the U.S. National Park Service has assembled 419 protected units, of which 62 hold the ‚Äúnational park‚Äù designation. To visit all 63 of these treasures one would need to travel to 29 states and two U.S. territories.
But with so many national parks to visit, there are trails, craters, and lakeshores that can be explored responsibly and without crowds. How remote and uncrowded are these parks? Katmai National Park‚Äôs Aniakchak caldera is so remote that many park rangers have‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to eat your way through San Diego like a local
entry.summary:
Mexican food and seafood are the obvious choices when visiting¬†San Diego. The culinary scene capitalizes on year-round perfect weather with rooftop terraces and oceanfront dining views. But the diversity of food options doesn‚Äôt stop at tacos.
¬†One neighborhood honors its historical heritage with authentic Italian restaurants, while another dedicates itself to representing the many cultures and flavors of Asian cuisine. Local craft beer is omnipresent, too. At local farmers‚Äô markets and restaurants, seasonal ingredients are showcased and usually plucked straight from one of the county‚Äôs 5,000 farms during peak ripeness.
Travelers looking to whet their palate with the best food in Southern California should fill their itinerary with these essential dishes and culinary experiences f‚Ä¶
